name: Facing
description: Each creature has a facing direction that determines its front, sides, and rear arcs. Attacks from behind a creature's facing gain Advantage. This rule adds tactical depth to positioning in grid-based combat.

front.width: 3 squares (the square directly ahead and the two squares flanking it diagonally)
front.effect: No special benefit or penalty for attackers

sides.width: The squares to the left and right that are not in the front or rear arcs
sides.effect: No special benefit or penalty for attackers

rear.width: The 3 squares directly behind the creature (opposite the front arc)
rear.effect: Attacks from the rear arc have Advantage

mechanics.changingFacing: A creature can change its facing direction at any point during its move at no additional movement cost. A creature can also use its Reaction to change its facing direction when any creature it can see moves.
mechanics.shields: When using this variant, a shield's AC bonus applies only against attacks from the front and side arcs, not from the rear arc.
limitations: Facing is tracked only on a grid; this rule is not used in theater-of-the-mind combat
Creatures with All-Around Vision or similar traits are immune to rear-arc Advantage

interactions: When combined with the flanking variant rule, facing can make positioning even more powerful; DMs may choose to use one or the other, not both
Rogues benefit significantly since rear attacks grant Advantage, enabling Sneak Attack more easily
Shield-users must be more careful about rear attacks since the shield bonus does not apply from the rear
Reactions to change facing add strategic cost since the creature cannot use its Reaction for opportunity attacks or other features that turn
